p: While we have so far largely discussed virus dynamics on the level of the host population, there are equally important processes to be considered on the within-host level. The “kinetics” of viral infection arise from a complex array of factors including viral replication and variability, the dynamics of the immune response, and pathogenicity to the host [ 91]. Over the past two decades, mathematical models have played an important role in studying these dynamics, often motivated by the need to understand the actual and potential impact of interventions such as treatment or immunization [ 91– 93].
